WRITING.TEXT: Ett av problemen jag hr ocks, r att folk tycker det r svrt att lsa in sig p frgestllningen nr den r p engelska. Det behvs svenska subtitles till de filmer p tuben som anvnds som info fr acta ocks antagligen. S mkt att gra, s lite tid.... :(
...och jag som precis tnkte lnka upp till den och tacka fr maillistan! Jag har nmligen lnkat hit till den hr trden, i inlgget. Tack Janne och tack Shakti213!

Damn, this post of yours really got me thinking, thanks icanjusttypeanythi. About how we live in a period of "change" in all sorts of ways. Where using technology not necessarily means knowledge acquired by and for profession(al)s anymore, but has become a sort of enhancer for every day life.
For instance, my system camera collects dust on the shelf, I almost always use my phone. I instagram my days, and even though I certainly look for the esthetics around me, it's more of a journal-making tool to be honest. It's personal, not professional. No matter if it's grainy as shit, it's fun.
No doubt certain professions will disappear, the photographer as a profession is probably no exception of risking that. Come to think of it, I read a while back that a purse brand was planning to let their customers provide images for their next ad campaign, as they regarded the technical equipment people have within easy reach in every-day life, would be good enough.
I guess I shouldn't be surprised, many are the professions that has disappeared into memory. I somehow never really considered "living a change" first hand, like this. And so fast! When I started working we used fonts made of glass in the very first computerized monster machines (Berthold), on light sensitive papers, that we developed in a darkroom. This we put up on a table, cut up and waxed in order for it to stick. That was the layout process. We usually didn't even see a photo, next to it, until it was printed. And back then, the old guys talked about when they started out, how they used lead fonts and proof read stuff backwards/upside down.
Today, I take a picture, write a text, lay it out on my laptop, publish it... It IS a change, and to think that things will remain the same considering the kind of times we live in, is probably not very realistic. However, I'm not entirely sure it's a bad thing. Sad to an extent, yes, but might not be bad.
Photojournalism will most likely be watered down with "people close by with a phone", if photos will be required at all in this youtube age. Art photography has always been difficult to make a living of, most that does that "work for a living" taking on all sorts of projects. I even saw a sneak-peak of an upcoming filter in Photoshop, that basically removed motion blurr, so in theory the art of keeping a camera steady, isn't even going to be a big thing.
On the surface it sounds kind of sad, but I can't help but wonder what the drive and talent that this profession still in some manner has encapsulated in the past, will lead to in the future? New professions, new imagins, new heights of how to document the world as it progresses, perhaps even?
I hope so at least.
Thanks again for thought provoking text, it will stay with me for a while I think.

[This](http://www.ted.com/talks/lang/en/johanna_blakley_lessons_from_fashion_s_free_culture.html) may also be relevant. Johanna Blakley's TED-speak about how the fashion industry work, in regards of copyright.

Ah, the ol' "a comics reward is getting a woman to laugh". I've always percieved that as somewhat rude to hard working comedians, to be honest. Many comedians do tell tales of how they saved themselves from bullies and similar in school by being the class clown. Making people laugh, instead of receiving a punch. This is most likely not true to everybody out there, making a living out of laughter, but it seems quite common. So I think making people laugh as a professional somewhere was about making an impression. I guess impressing women isn't excluded, but they do tend to want to impress men as well.
Now, I've wondered why I mostly found male stand up comedians to be funnier than female. For me it was a bit of an epiphany a few years back when I realized that it ultimately was due to the discomfort of watching a woman pushing the envelope. If she too does it, who's left to be responsible? Stupidity, of course, but quite good for me to realize, so that I could kick that silly role-reflex.

I find it strange and somewhat disconcerting that the language signals that women are supposed to "give" sex as opposed to men who "have" it. Pardon my generalization, but it appears to me that this is some underlying notion that I almost always find in discussions like these. I wonder if the sort of situation the OP describes would be all that common, if men and women alike, were "having sex" (which in reality I think most do) instead of this, in every-day speech sounds like one party being somebody who's supposed to give something away, rather than having it?
(I'm a bit of a language nerd, I admit, but it's interesting to analyze what kind of signals we unknowingly send out when choosing our words, and what kind of impact that has.)

The most important thing, I think, is for you to realize that you can not solve your mother's issues. Even if she, in her mind, regards you as one of them. Her problems are something she has to want to deal with. So I think the first step needs to be for you to figure out how you let go of the feelings of responsibility for her, that I imagine reading between the lines.
You will be able to help yourself, if you let yourself. You are no longer 15 years old, depending on your mother, even if that emotion probably stays with you as a ghost companion through life. I know it has for me.
I went through the process of "breaking up" with my father, who simply wasn't good for me and my state of mind. Realizing that a parent isn't what you need him/her to be, is extremely painful. But I hope that you understand that the pain deep down derives from the knowledge that you deserve better. Don't feel any shame.
Quite simply, realize that you are not the one who is ill.
I have to say, you already look absolutely gorgeous!

Yeah, this is true -- as it is with women as well, blurting out generelizing sexistic jokes or whatnot. I tried to explain this to a bunch of guys I hang with in a chat, the problem isn't the odd sexistic joke, it's finding yourself in a situation where you get slammed by loads of jokes which ultimately makes you feel "alright, I'm the odd one out, please continue to remind me, why don't you". I dunno, it's the ganging-up effect that gets to me personally, not the jokes. Even though I know it's meant as a joke from each individual it easily turns into a grey area of social bonding between others, where I'm providing the glue without being included.
I'm so glad that I wasn't alone in this - squeezed my eyes to see if something unseemly was printed on it.
I'm guessing men talk to men, and women to women. Think we're on to something here, perhaps they should talk to eachother? ;)

I've actually thought about this many times - several of my female friends in their forties complain about their hubbys not being into sex often enough. But when you read around and watch the telly, it would appear to be the other way around. Never made any sense to me.
I found [this](http://www.democraticunderground.com/discuss/duboard.php?az=view_all address=132x1006850) - apparantly from a few years back, directed to then president Bush.

What bad business? They make [more profits](http://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/news/2011/11/piracy-problems-us-copyright-industries-show-terrific-health.ars) than most other industries in the US. It's kind of sad that Hollywood makes more money than ever, and still it's argued that they need help keeping the business afloat. Some serious PR-magic at work, almost impressive.

There we go - transferred the four domains I had there. It wasn't as easy as purchasing a domain, no surprise there... I transfered it to a Swedish domain handler, that according to the support I called does not support SOPA. Couldn't find any mail address to let Godaddy know why, so I simply sent a support ticket. http://yfrog.com/z/nwjoofp

I'm all for keeping a cool head, mature strategies to make the world a better place and whatnot. You don't shout revolution 'cause you wake up bored one day, change has got to be regarded seriously, I totally agree with that notion. But is it really rational to suggest that the measure of maturity in this case, is that somebody else gives you permission to object to the state of things?
It's seems to me that rights of freedom to assembly is pitted against rights of land owners. It puts the whole protest thing into a nutshell, if you ask me, as an onlooker from Europe. Who decides which rights the police are to protect when things like this happens? Who decides if you have any rights, check the Department of Transportation..? It gives me a chill, to be honest.
It's this, the apparant clash between ownership and civil rights, that makes this whole debate so confusing. One group's rights has to take a back seat, I would assume? It sorta has to be some sort of clash, seeing how various rights are pitted against eachother?

Not that I feel particularily sorry for repeat offenders having to go to jail, but, when has a criminal "paid his/her debt to society", is what I keep wondering about this system? Seems to me that it's already decided the first times around how much time a crime is due to society. Are the first two rounds lighter in punishment in the hopes that they don't return to criminal lifestyles? Just how does that work?

Whenever somebody's completely sure about something, it's an indication (in my mind) that this person probably don't know enough. It's always easier to be sure, the less you know. Simply put, I believe that people aren't nearly as clever as they think they are.
It's always self confidence that makes a man, or woman for that matter, good looking.
...yes, I'm typing through a time machine.
Goodness, I feel cheap! ;)

aw, never! However, it's more a matter of daring to do something I haven't done before. Ask something on reddit. It is kind of a rush, actually, now that I think about it. :) I really didn't intend to come off as angry or anything, I'm quite amazed that it can be read like that. You learn something everyday, I suppose.
hahaha, I wish. Nope, on my way to work, sober. But perhaps suffering a tad from mondays...?

Oh I see, it's the issue that seems off, not the language! Well, like I wrote to somebody else - that is a good thing, if that's the case. It's not like I want to be right. However, right here on reddit and other places online, I keep [stumbling over](http://www.reddit.com/r/videos/comments/jhilx/i_am_just_going_to_leave_this_here_for_everyone/) the opposite notion, that it's not alright for girls to have some sort of sexuality thing going. I might have misunderstood it, though. ;)
I'm sorry, being Swedish has it's drawbacks I suppose. At least I try to make myself understood in other languages. I'll try to better myself.
Good advice. I'll try to refrain from inhaling while drinking, though!
Thanks, this is what I mean. Loads of people do give a damn, of course, the trick is most likely not to care.

Well, all in all that would be good news! ;) I just can't shake the feeling that it's not alright to have a healthy sexuality as a woman, and on the other hand, men has to be all out sexual being in all things, even though they don't necessarily function that way as a person.

WRITING.TITLE: Why does women "have" to be responsible while men happily fap away?
WRITING.TEXT:
It's one of those things that really messes with my head. Why can't I be, uhm, pardon my french, horny? Put up, but don't like it, is broadcasted everywhere. Like, where men have **sexuality**, women have **responsibility**.
I see it everywhere, how girls and women should be ashamed of themselves, when they display some sort of sexual notion--or just look sexy even, however, are shrudes if they don't "give a little" sometimes. Like sex is some frigging prize in a competition or whatnot? It's such a mood killer being the one to have to "give sex" instead of just being free to "have sex", like any normal human being.
In contrast, I also have several friends who lie awake at night wondering why their hubbies isn't interested in having sex anymore. Men, of course, also has to live up to something that necessarily isn't what they are about. It just appears that roles have been assigned way to narrowly for something that in a sense makes the world go around.
It blows my mind how many problems that would be solved should this weird contradiction just be left in the past and become a distant memory of crazy old-days stuff. Do you know if it has some purpose that explains why it's around?
Luckily some don't give a damn and do what comes natural to them, I applaud them, but still there are some sort of general stereotypical "thruth" that everybody has to relate to, in one way or another. It gives me the creeps. Is there anything that can be done to change this?
Guess I'll have to blame the allergies coming to work all red-eyed from crying. Thanks for posting, this was extraordinarily beautiful.
Chances are that the stress that several display here (not finding out instantly what the question and answers were) might be something they regret living by, down the line.

Considering the amount of fapping comments I've come across, I'm surprised to see the readiness to question this girls sexuality. Amazing also, that a sexy girl apparantly is an alright excuse to be an asshole. When is it wrong to be an asshole, fapping to nuns? You know you did it.

You know, any sort of empathy regarding the underlying reasons for the riots/looting vanishes when watching this. :( One would hope that people would have liked to be better than those that they disgust - thieving or dishonest politicians.
I'm assuming out of fear. Watched another video of policemen retreating, so I guess civil courage isn't at an all time high over all. http://yfrog.com/0wtduz

I think it's because it's simply easier to focus fear and anger to a Darth Vader type of character, ie somebody that isn't like you in any way. When too close, it's like having to consider your own part in autrocities which is rather horrible. However, all of us must most likely have to accept the fact that our "political incorrectnesses" can be used as validation for revolutionary acts. I doubt very much that it has anything to do with wich 'ism is being used as justification though, people seems to be people regardless of conviction...

Loads of great advice here, but miss one thing that also could be important. Find ways of keeping track of your daughter, don't make it entirely about what you're about, try to find ways to show that you want to know what she's about and what's going on in her life. Talking to her mother or stepfather might be one thing. Like asking for pictures and snippets of what's going on with her. In the long run it's not just her getting to know you, I guess she would like it, if you knew her as well. Just a thought.
Wow, just what the doctor ordered!

WRITING.TITLE: Linda Hamilton asks to be Ray Lewis' date to Marine Corps Ball as Betty White had to turn him down

WRITING.TEXT: It's not a matter of "how much", for me personally. It's more a matter of "for God's sake, stop harrassing file sharers" and let's not forget the accompanying goal of herding people on the internet, providing the content certain companies alone may charge for. As long as that continues, it's not ever going to be a matter of a price tag, I'm sorry to say. It's always going to be too expensive to watch basic civil rights go down the drain.
I swear, sometimes my pinkie has a will of its own! ;D
oh, no worries! The commas, by the way, have caused some amusing misunderstandings when Swedish accounting reports have been translated into English, and vice versa.

Actually, in Europe it even differs between countries how they write thousands. In Sweden, for instance, we have a space instead of a comma (or point), like this: 1 000. And we use commas fr decimals, 1,00.

I'm not sure, think it has to do with guilt. "I've agreed to do this, so I have to comply to that". It's quite common that victims of abuse blame themselves, and it's not unheard of people staying in abusive relationships for years. Kind of feeds the guilt too, doesn't it, "you're in the situation willingly, so..." Some even end up in one abusive relationship after another. Some shit in life you have to bear and grin, I suppose, in order to gain whatever, reckon we all can acknowledge that to a degree. No idea why and when that turns selfdestructive in some though. I do feel rather sad that some people prey on that. Especially after viewing this horrendeous account.

Silver lining; this inspired me to register here at reddit, after having lurked here quite a while. I just would like to know - when the government creates commercials like these, am I right to assume it's funded by tax payers' money? I figured it a bit odd that the video isn't allowed to comment on or rate, in light of that. Also, is this aired on american tv-networks? (I'm Swedish and unsure how it works.)
